job_title: Employment Specialist/Job Coach for People With Disabilities
pros: Seeing the progress clients make on thier interpersonal and work skills at thier own jobs makes you feel like your job is worth doing! Being a job coach allows you to work in a variety of settings, (stores, restaurants, family owned businesses) instead of an office like a regular job. The change of scenery multiple times a day helps the day to go by quickly! You are allowed freedom with your schedule as long as you let the manager know ahead of time. This is a great job for college students! This job requires a lot of driving. You are allowed to use your own car (with mileage reimbursed) or use the company car. You can listen to music while you drive! Most of the time, you are just observing people with disabilities work (your clients) and giving them pointers. You aren’t always hands on with all clients, depending on thier needs and preferences. This helps negate stress by not having to talk all day long.
cons: You will only see your co-workers for brief interactions. This can lead to feeling isolated. Often working on skills and tasks with clients can seem mundaine or discouraging when they don’t seem to make visible progress. (I.e. trying to teach a client to clean an appliance more efficiently and they do it incorrectly for weeks or months) Some clients have negative attitudes and may say insulting or demeaning comments to thier co workers or even yourself. This is part of the job -to help them with communication skills, but can be taxing if the issues don’t get resolved after months on end. There isn’t any advancement for the position of job coach. It is ideal for someone who either doesn’t have a degree or wants experience in human services right after college.

pros: Flexibility in hours, face time with some lovely customers.
cons: Heavy work load, always chasing your own tail. Mentally and physically demanding.

review_title: Great people, fulfilling work, flexible scheduling (great for students)
job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Corvallis, OR
pros:
- The staff are super friendly and helpful with providing the necessary training
- The scheduling is very flexible, so it's great for students or those who need part-time work
- It's pretty enjoyable and low-stress work most of the time; a lot of simply hanging out, going out in the community, eating group lunches, etc.
cons: - Genuinely can't think of too many. If you're willing to accept the job, and if you don't mind a bit of note-taking/reporting, you'll have no issues

review_title: Meaningful work and a great company
job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Corvallis, OR
pros: This was a job where I felt I was really making a positive impact. I learned new skills and got to work in a variety of environments. They were great at working with my schedule, and they treated all their employees really well!
cons: I had no complaints at this company.

pros: Money is a very good pro
cons: Driving is a very good con

The Direct Support Professional position involves being creative in the ways you support individuals.

Very flexible hours, which is wonderful for students.
cons: Every so often there is a schedule change based on supported individuals needs, which means you may show up to work and not know what you are doing that day.

pros: Excellent opportunities to advance your career

Great team. They really care about the people they support and appreciate their employees. Nobody acts as if they are better than anyone else. The admin team, management, and staff are all very supportive and work as a team.
cons: The pay is not great, but they fight for higher pay for personal support workers and just gave some nice raises.

cons: Pretty much everything. Administration doesn't care about you, and have even gone as far as to call those working with clients "replaceable." Lousy pay (not a lot of that is their fault, but you should see the checks admin brings in compared to the people). They will work you hours and hours and don't want to hear anything negative. I can't say more about how much they suck.
